JACKIE: Today, we're excited
to have Professor Regina Nuzzo with us. As a deaf woman,
Regina's journey up

has been anything but easy,
and from earning her PhD in a male-dominated
field to writing about sex science
for a major newspaper

and learning how to hear new
sounds with a cochlear implant, Regina has consistently
blazed her own trail

in the pursuit of her passions. In this keynote, Regina
will share her story. She'll share the challenges she
faced along the way, lessons

she learned, and advice
she has to offer. Regina is an expert
in storytelling, using

data analysis and statistics. Her work has been featured in
Nature, Los Angeles Times, New

York Times, Reader's Digest, New
Scientist, Scientific American, and more. And currently, she's
teaching statistics

in American Sign Language
at Gallaudet University, the world's only liberal arts
college for deaf and hard

of hearing students. Thank you for
being here, Regina, and I'll now pass the controls
over you after which we'll

have a Q&A session. So please feel free to
continue to submit questions. Regina, please go
ahead and present.

REGINA NUZZO: Wonderful. Thank you so much Jackie
for the invitation. To come and speak, I'm honored.

I'm delighted. I thought about today, any words
of wisdom and pieces of advice,

and I'm not sure I
have too much wisdom. But I do have a story to tell.

And some of the things I decided
to talk about for this story, it's really the first time
I'll be talking about them

in public. So I really appreciate that we
have this lovely space for me

to do that, and thank you
all for listening and being here for that.
Well, Jackie said, I am deaf. What does that even mean, deaf?

I never know how to identify
myself, how to label myself. Deaf, is it hard of hearing?

Is it hearing impaired? Is it someone with
a cochlear implant? Is it a cyborg?
It's not easy. I get it. We need labels.

We need identity. In the past, we all would
have known each other.

You would have known me. We'd be in the
same neighborhood, and you would have more
nuanced information about me.
What did I hear? Did I grow up signing?

What does that even-- my background. You would have that, and I
would have that about you.

So I get that we need to
have these categorical labels

and identity, but it
still makes it difficult, especially when they're
categories, when they're these rigid categories.

So my question is, well, deaf
compared to what or to whom, right?

I'm a statistician. I got my PhD at Stanford,
and statisticians are always

saying, well, compared to what? Well, who's the control group? And because compared to animals
like dogs, and cats, and bats,

we are all very
hearing impaired. Did you know? I discovered this
when I was looking up.

Cats can hear the
electrical outlet when you plug in like your
hairdryer or lamp or something.

Before you even turn it
on, they hear that buzzing. They have an immense range of
hearing that we don't have.

So I'm wondering
whether cats are always going around, secretly
pitying us for being so deaf

and not being able to hear
all the beautiful things in the world that they can hear. And cats, it's probably true.

So for me, I was born with
about half the hearing

that most babies would. And I could hear the
low frequencies but not

the high frequencies. I could hear-- that
means I could hear things like dogs, and thunder,
and vowel sound,

but I couldn't hear
the consonants, the high-pitched
sounds, rain, birds.

I couldn't hear birds. The birds was actually
the way that they found my hearing loss.

I was about 4, and
my mother said, hey, did you know that the bird's
beautiful this morning.
And I said, bird? Mom, birds don't make a noise. I'd never heard birds. I didn't know they made a noise.

So that was when they caught it. This is my audiogram. It doesn't matter if you don't
know how to read an audiogram.

This is an example
of my audiogram. Perfect hearing would
be straight line.

Up at the top at the top,
on the zero hearing loss, and you can see where
mine was going down.

So everything under the
curve, I was able to hear. This is my audiogram when I
was probably about six or so.

So you can see that I
had the low frequencies, but I pretty much had none
of the high frequencies, including the birds.

The problem is that those high
frequencies, those consonants, are where so much of the
information for words are,

so might, tight, light, fight. If it's important
that I distinguish

the difference between
them, I couldn't hear them. It was just high. And if it was in
background noise, I would lose it
completely, just gone.

So this is my audiogram
when I was about 20. I was losing hearing over time.

The graphics are nice. They explain why I
was able to learn how to speak because I
have these low frequencies,

these vowels. But I would mispronounce or not
pronounce the high frequency things, things
that I didn't hear

or I couldn't see
on people's lips. It's also kind of fun to look
at what's called a spectrogram.

So again, you don't have
to worry about reading it. This is a spectrogram of
someone saying, "19th century",

difficult to pronounce. The frequencies are
along the y-axis, and time is along the x-axis.

And the color--
it's a heat map-- show you the intensity
or the volume.

So this is what a person
with normal hearing would hear, kind of all of
these colors coming forth.

They would be able to hear that. When I was a kid
this, is what I heard,

like blankness, and
then a tiny little bit. I made great use of that
tiny little bit of sound.

I was really good at
guessing, reading people, kind of understanding what
they might be saying,

and bluffing, and getting by. This is my spectrogram
after I lost more hearing.

This was about when I
was 20, so it was just going down and down. And my parents didn't really
know how much I was struggling

or how much I was missing. They sent me to normal
school, no sign language,

no special accommodations. And philosophically, I
find it kind of interesting

to look back because I didn't
know what I was missing either. I think it's this way
with a lot of things.

How do you know what you're
missing if you've never experienced it before?

You all are not going
around sad and depressed because you're not hearing
what your cat is hearing. I wasn't either.

I just didn't know there
was this whole other world, and theoretically, I knew. But I wasn't really.

It's not until
several decades later that I, as an adult, middle
age, got a cochlear implant

and then was able
to get more sound and to really realize
how much I was missing.

And I have so much sympathy
for my younger self. It's hard.

It's hard. A deaf friend of
mine described it as doing crossword puzzles
in real time, where you're

constantly having to fill in
the blanks, and the clues, and do these mental gymnastics
with your giant machine

learning algorithm. Except I wasn't
a super computer. I was just this
tired little girl.

So I would go to school every
day, and not hear my teachers,

and look down at the book
in my lap, and just read. Probably a good way to get
an education or not horrible.

I would go to the
lunchroom in the cafeteria, and the cacophony
of kids, shouting,

and talking to each other,
and building connections. And I just--

I couldn't understand a thing. Sorry, it's a little emotional. I couldn't understand,
so I was so isolated
being in that situation. I didn't really have friends.

And then to top it all
off, I would go home and pass out with
fatigue, take a nap,

just from the bare
minimum trying to get by. Still, I loved school.

I loved it. It's no surprise
that I gravitated

towards math and
reading because these were things in black and white.

They didn't change. Things in the air were
just not reliable. They were coming in. It was like they weren't real.

They were ephemeral, things
that I could read and see.

So thinking about
math and reading,

have you ever in your life
realized themes in your life but only in retrospect
you didn't realize kind

of at the moment what was
guiding you and what was there? One of the themes for me
has been communication,

and it's precisely
because I could never take clear communication
for granted because I was

so confused all the time
by the world, and left out, and all this information.

I studied engineering at
University of South Florida, and it was hard, deaf wise.

Big auditoriums, I couldn't
even read lips now.

I was a little better
when I was in upper class, but then often I was the
only female in the class.

And I think a lot of you know
what that experience is like, not a whole lot of fun,
not nurturing or warm.

I didn't have a whole lot
of support in that way. But I was drawn to
statistics, and I

think part of it,
again, part of the theme because statistics
does in a sense what

I was doing what I
do every day, which is take this mass of complicated
messy, incomplete information

what the universe is trying
to tell you what it means, what reality is underneath all
of that, do something with it.

In some ways, that's a terrific
metaphor for my hearing loss

and I think this
is one of these-- again, one of these
examples of this theme or about me taking pieces
in my life, what it is,

and obstacles, brokenness,
or feeling of brokenness

and not being something I
need to overcome, or embrace, or something but, in a
whole different direction,

taking it and creatively
integrating it into my life and to who I am in ways
that make sense to me.

and that was life
changing, I have to say. And it's not just because I'm
speaking to people at Stanford.

It was amazing. It was hard. It was very hard. Now, it's just a whole
other level of hard.

We all suffered. My cohort was brilliant,
and everyone suffered. Amazing there.

Still good friends
with a lot of them. I got through it with a lot
of support and the people that I met at Stanford.

We're still good friends,
collaborate with them. At Stanford, I didn't-- there's no textbook to read.

The faculty were the textbook. They were better
than the textbook. Nothing to read. You need to get
everything from them.

So it was challenging. My hearing loss was
also going down fast

at that time because
of the stress. I don't know. They call my type of hearing
loss a ski slope hearing loss

because it kind of
resembles the ski slope. And you could just
see, year after year, these audiograms, that
slope just crumbling,

and rotting away, and eroding. It was tough. So it was at Stanford that I got
my first pair of hearing aids.

They didn't work very well
in the '70s growing up and I had an odd
type of hearing loss, so I got my first
pair of hearing aids.

That was great. I also learned about
assistive technology, and that was the first
time that I found out

about real-time captioning
with a transcriptionist like we have today. A human would sit
and do the phonetics

of what they're hearing, and
words would magically appear in the laptop between us. So I requested that for
my weekly biostat seminar,

and that was great. Some of the professors would
come and sit next to me,

kind of look over my shoulder. I think these sorts of
things, universal design, captions help a lot of people.

You don't need to
have a deafness. I also started learning American
Sign Language at Stanford

with a fabulous instructor
Cathy Haas, who's deaf.

She was amazing. It was my first real exposure
to deaf culture, ASL,

and all of that. I'd been so busy
exhausting myself, trying to fit into the hearing world
that I never really explored

this other thing. And I was not a
beautiful signer, but Cathy is like
the best instructor.

She gave me my sign name,
and just kind of she planted the seed, that very
gentle seed, very patient,

that didn't sprout until later. And I think sometimes
that's all we need,

someone who's just going
to plant a seed, not push, not trying to influence,
just plant a seed. And I feel like with
Cathy, that was me.

But it took years before
that really sprouted. So I graduate Stanford
and was doing a postdoc

at McGill University,
but I still have this communication
thing on my brain. I really wanted to communicate
and write about statistics.

I had taught at Stanford. I loved it. And I wanted to connect
with a broader audience. And a friend of mine was doing
the science communication

program at UC Santa
Cruz, and basically, they take scientists
and in nine months

turn them into
science journalists. So it's great. I went, I did that. I loved it.

It's a little bit of an
odd career choice, though, on the face of it, so
to be hearing impaired

and yet do a job that requires
you to listen for a living.

So I had to learn how to
be creative about that. I worked at The Monterey
Herald throughout my time

in the school there,
and I much preferred to do the stories about
ladybugs, and sea lions,

and grunion fish on the beach
than the ones with people because it was easier to
interview the ladybugs.

I went to this
desalination town hall, and covering it for The
Herald, and supposed

to come back with quotes of
what people said at the meeting, and I couldn't hear a thing.

I came back with a notebook that
was nearly completely blank.

Luckily, I had a wonderful
editor who just was very calm and looked me square
in the eye and said, do we need to kill the story?

It'd be a bad thing
killing a story. Luckily, we were able
to cobble it together,

but that was not for me. I prefer doing other
things, and the thing

is I was trying too hard to be
like other people or a model

of what a journalist is
supposed to do instead of being more like me with all
its wonderful imperfections.
So there's a thing-- what is it called? Kintsugi, golden repair.

And it's this idea that you
have something that's broken

but rather there's
these pieces-- but rather than getting rid
of it, just tossing it out,

you repair it with
this lacquer that's tinged with shiny gold,
platinum, or silver, or gold,

or something. And you have something that
is beautiful and strong

in its own way. And yes, it doesn't
look like everyone else or do things like everyone
else, but it is itself.

It is its own bowl. And that was what I needed
to do with journalism.

I don't want to call it a secret
superpower, but it was mine.

It was those bits
that I was most

missing or deficient on that
became my source of strength.

So instead of being
this perfect journalist,

I was a journalist who
could not hear very well, but I was very
good at listening.

And what does listening mean? So I learned to
listen in other ways. I learned to listen just for
the couple of good quotes.

I didn't need all the quotes. Or I realized I
could listen better when I was interviewing someone
if I did all my research ahead

of time. So I'd read everything
written by a researcher before I went to
interview them, and then I

would be able to ask them
all the great questions that other journalists
might not have even thought to do because they
hadn't needed to compensate

and do this other thing. Or my writing instructor
said that he thought

that I noticed things
in the scene that maybe other people wouldn't have,
someone nervously twirling

their chair, or what
they were doing, and these are
great color details that you can put into a story.
So this, that was me. I had fun with it.

Jackie said, I ended up
writing for LA Times, and somehow I ended up
writing a big feature

story on the science of
orgasms, which you can imagine might have been popular,
especially at the time.

It was a little
racy at the time, but it was straight-up science. So then I ended up writing a lot
about sex science for LA Times.

I was on The Today
Show talking about how to use evolutionary psychology
research tricks to get

a date at a holiday party
and the silly things, but it was a lot of fun for me.

That was me that was
taking these pieces and creatively integrating
them into who I wanted to be.

And I've done that
with other things, too. So after I finished the
writing program, I came to DC

and worked for the National
Academy of Sciences as a writer, but I
really wanted to write for a general audience. And I missed teaching.

And Gallaudet, as it
happened, is in DC and had a position open, tenure
track, assistant professor

in mathematics. And for those of
you that don't know, Gallaudet is unlike
any other place

in the world, the
only University that is set up expressly for deaf
and hard-of-hearing students.

And so there I was,
new assistant professor

taking on this challenge. And it was strange because
here at Gallaudet, I
was no longer hearing impaired. Now I was signing impaired. I knew sign language.

Cathy did a great job. But it was nothing
like the fluency. I was working with
faculty who were

second, third, fourth
generation deaf. They were native in the
ASL, and it's really hard to go from rudimentary
survival skills

to let's talk about
advanced statistics. But I loved it.

I love the challenge
because, again, that's just communication. I love communicating
complicated ideas.

It's basically what
I do as a journalist. And I love the challenge of
doing this in a language--

ASL is just so beautiful but it
is not like any other language. It's spatial. It's four dimensional.

It doesn't have
vocabulary for things. So how are we going to
talk about correlation?

What sign are we going to use
when we talk about correlation? What does it mean? What does correlation
really mean? I love that.

That has been fun, and I think-- just like being deaf
it made me a better journalist and a
better listener,

I think that teaching in
my non-native language, this amazing but very
unlike written or spoken

English language, it's made
me a better teacher and better communicator. I've had to be creative
and put me in sync

about these sorts of things. It also got me down this path
of developing this new subfield

of quantitative
communication, so how can we take numbers and data
and talk about them in ways

that bypass the brain-- so brains are notoriously
bad at numbers-- and just get right
to our gut somehow?

To me, this is-- it's kind of embodied the same
thing as kind of what ASL does.

Anyway, so I have one more
example on this personal level of how creative integration
has worked in my life,

and I don't even know if
I can take credit for it. It's more like
what my brain did.

So about seven years ago, I
decided after a lot of research I wanted a cochlear implant.

I wanted to give it a try. I wanted to hear birds. I wanted to hear birds for
the first time in my life and lots of other
things-- the S sound.

So I'm happy to talk
more about the cochlear implant in the Q&A, but
basically, it's this--

I call it-- I named my
tiny brain computer, tiny. So you have a tiny mini computer
that bypasses your damaged

cochlea and directly stimulates
your auditory nerve leading into your brain, and thousands
of pulses, electricity,

thousands of times per second. That's what's
happening right now. And amazingly, your
brain is supposed

to make sense of all of this. So I did this as a
middle-aged adult, and I didn't sync my brain.

I had no idea if my brain
would be plastic enough to be able to make sense of it.

So you have to wait three
weeks before you're turned on, activated. And I went in the room-- you
probably have seen videos
of kids sitting there-- and turned it on.
And she said something. I don't even know what it was. And it sounded so bizarre.

It was not even human. It was like alien things
being beamed in my head.

It was so-- and then
I started laughing. And then I heard that,
which sounded even funnier,

and then that made
me laugh more. So it was a very
interesting thing. It was also very
painful, though.

So when she did the S
sound, finally the s sound. I was ready.
I was going to get it. Oh, it-- I didn't hear it.

It was completely silent. I felt it, and I saw it, like
this bright white icicle needle

being pierced through my brain. But I did not hear the sound,
like completely silent. I know what sounds
sound like, but it's

this way with all
these high frequencies. So S-H sound sounded like--

looked like, felt like-- it didn't sound like anything. It felt like an iceberg,
all the high frequencies.

So I had synesthesia,
synesthesia. I never had that before.

It wasn't until I got activated
that all of a sudden now all

the vowels that I had before,
those low frequencies, they came through as like
colors, muddy colors,

and Earth tone colors. And all the high frequencies,
ones I had never heard and the ones that maybe I had
heard when I was much younger,

they came through with
these like chrome, this beautiful chrome, edging
around this muddy, middle,
bright and shiny. It felt like a cool breeze.

I couldn't make sense of it. I had synesthesia. So those of you
that have studied

a little bit about
neuroscience probably have already guessed what's
likely to have happened.

My brain, as a young child,
never had exposure at all to those high frequency sounds,
and brains are very thrifty.

That was valuable real
estate, and it was not going to let that just go vacant. So it was likely
remapped by the visual

in the somatosensory
parts of my brain that were kind of next door.

Only now, as middle-aged adult,
I was telling my brain, nope, we're going to do sounds.

It would be like, well, first of
all, I got so much extra sound, it was like you hearing
now what a bat hears.

That's how much extra
sound that I got. But imagine, OK, what does
an ultrasound sound like?

It's hard for you
to imagine, right? Imagine that all of a
sudden overnight you

were able to taste it, or
kind of see it, or feel it, but you couldn't hear it.

It was the strangest thing. So it was frustrating
also because I

wanted to be able
to parse words, and I wanted to hear the S
sound and I can't, and all these high frequencies,
the consonants.

So I would just sit with my app. It would say a
word over and over, and I have to guess what it
is-- fight, tight, might.

And the more I
clenched and the more I tried to force my brain into
hearing those high frequency

sounds, making them
work, the worse it got.

And I worked very hard at this. I studied a little bit
about neuroplasticity, and so I played games with
myself to reward myself.

I did it while exercising. I had-- I was into this. I was completely into this
because I wanted it to work.
And also I was curious. What is it like? What's going on with my brain?

So I eventually discovered
that I couldn't clench and tell
my brain what to do.

It was just going
to do what it was. So I learned somehow I
could get into this state

where I would feel for
the sounds, so if it was--

the word was game, I would hear
G, this kind of muddy thing

with-- it's like a little crown or
little cap of gold on top.
I know it's weird, but.  So when I would--

if I were to hear
game, I wouldn't know if it was maim
or name, but if I

knew that if I
could feel that it had that little
golden crown on top, then I knew, OK,
so that was game.

And so this is a
bizarre way to learn how to hear because,
again, it's like tasting.

You have to taste for your
sounds instead of hearing it. You have to meld these
two things together. But this is what
my brain gave me

because my brain did
this golden repair. I think it's really beautiful
because this is actually

a great visual metaphor
for what it did. It took all these muddy kind
of things, this broken plate,

and edged it all in gold,
and stitched it all up, and made it its own thing.

And it was beautiful. Eventually, my brain
and I got along,

and synesthesia started to fade. The lightning bolts and the
crazy things started to fade.

And in some ways I miss it. I'm still able to get
that feeling back again,

of listening to music
and just crying, even

silly music, because
it had all these ornate little visual patterns to it.

Or listening to
someone speak, and it was like a cool, refreshing
breeze was over everything.

All those high
frequencies, I see them as being cool and crisp. I don't know.

So I went from not being able
to participate in conversation

at all in a noisy situation,
like hearing absolutely nothing, to being
able to survive.

It's not perfect. Nothing's perfect. My brain does what it
does, and that's it.

But it's OK. I made it me, and I think
that's what's important.

So thinking, OK, well, how
would I wrap up all this? I said no words of wisdom,
but three things maybe one

could take away from this. One is that assembling these
pieces in your life creatively,

integrating them
creatively, it's

powerful, difficult
but powerful, one of the most powerful
things you can do.

And number two,
as those bits that

seem most broken, almost
damaged, or almost missing,

those are actually the parts
that are the most beautiful, and strongest, and
a source of strength

if you can see them that way. And three, just I think
we are all capable of so
much more than we think we are. Thank you very much.

JACKIE: Hi, Regina. Thank you so much for
sharing that with us today. This was really moving
and inspirational,

and we really appreciate
your vulnerability, and talking about your
story in such detail,

and sharing with
us your journey. And as you and I were
talking about earlier, it just feels so much
more important now

to share that human
side of the journey and to be able to share
that with everyone and have that connection.

To everybody in the
audience, please continue to submit
your questions through the box below the
video, and we'll begin our Q&A

portion of the webinar today. We have some really
great questions that have come in for you,
Regina, during your talk.

And I want to start with the
first one that I feel really

kind of sums it up and is
a good one to start with. You've been asked, how
have you found the strength

to be so open and vulnerable
about your story today?

REGINA NUZZO: I think that
is an excellent question, how have I found-- I don't know. I was invited to be
here, and I did it.
Sometime that's all it takes.

I feel like this is a safe
space to be doing this. I do want to say that.

I don't know you
all, and everyone who might be watching this
later, I don't know you.

But I love the idea that
this has come together as a community, where
people support each other.

The other thing is that
I didn't have anyone telling me things about this
when I grew up or even for most
of my life, and it's hard if--

no, it's easier if you have
other people's stories, even if they're not
exactly like your own.

And I've been talking about
deafness, I should say, but I think all of this is a
metaphor for whatever thing

is your thing. Everyone has a thing, and
we all have multiple things. And so the idea that I can share
a little bit of that and maybe

other people can take
tiny little bits of that away and so, in a way, that's
supporting my younger self that

was so sad, and
alone, and confused. But thank you for the question.

JACKIE: Thanks, Regina. The next question is,
facing so many challenges in your journey,
is there anything

in particular that kept you
so motivated and persistent in achieving your goals? And do you have any
advice or insight

to share for other
women facing challenges in achieving their goals? REGINA NUZZO: Hmm, oh wow.

So just solve all the
problems right now. Just go ahead. [LAUGHS] When I was at Stanford,
we had a 50th anniversary

reunion for the
Stats Department, and all these alums were
coming back and hanging out. And I was talking to a guy
who was close to retirement.

I don't even remember his name. And I said, any advice for
a young person starting out?

And he said, have your own
career, the career that you want, not the career that
other people want you to have

or think you should have. And he said he always
regretted that he didn't, that he followed expectations.

And that actually stuck
with me, so I'm just going to pass that
one along again,

that it's difficult
to step off that path, and do something different,
and to strive, and work.

But in a way, what
alternative do you have, trying to be someone else? That has never worked.

So while it's harder
to be yourself, in the end, that's the only
thing you really can be.

JACKIE: Right, and finding
your own path along the way. REGINA NUZZO: There you go.  JACKIE: Absolutely. REGINA NUZZO:
Finding what's right.

JACKIE: But true. Another question
that came through-- and I thought this was really
